msgSnippet: The semantics of assertEquals() is essentially equals() lifted to nulls, in the sense that assertEquals(null, null) == true, rather than

The semantics of assertEquals() is essentially equals() "lifted" to nulls,
in the sense that assertEquals(null, null) == true, rather than
NullPointerException, which would be the case with null.equals(null). This
can be useful if you are testing that two objects are created correctly by
some (other) code (wrt the specification of how the objects should be
created), assuming a-priori that equals() on the actual objects is correct.

	static public void assertEquals(String message, Object expected,
Object actual) {
		if (expected == null && actual == null)
			return;
		if (expected != null && expected.equals(actual))
			return;
		failNotEquals(message, expected, actual);
	}



-----Original Message-----
From: Robert Sartin [mailto:sartin@...]
Sent: 21 February 2001 17:00
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] assertNotEquals


So far, every time I have wanted something like assertNotEquals has
been when I am testing the equals method. Somehow, I actually like it
better to test the equals method using:

  assert(testObject.equals(shouldEqual));
  assert(!testObject.equals(shouldNotEqual));

rather than assertEquals and the proposed assertNotEquals.

I haven't (yet) encountered situations where I want to assert
inequality for other reasons.

Regards,

Rob
